description: And Thompson, who played in Jacksonville from 2014-17, stated that former Jaguars top executive Tom Coughlin and Coach Doug Marrone told players they couldn't kneel during the playing of the national anthem in 2017..  "I specifically remember Tom Coughlin and Doug Marrone telling us we couldn't kneel," Thompson wrote. When the Jaguars played the Baltimore...
text:
Former Jaguars safety Peyton Thompson spoke out on Twitter that the NFL and
all of its organizations continue to release statements of fluff in the
aftermath of George Floyd's death.

And Thompson, who played in Jacksonville from 2014-17, stated that former
Jaguars top executive Tom Coughlin and Coach Doug Marrone told players they
couldn't kneel during the playing of the national anthem in 2017.

"I specifically remember Tom Coughlin and Doug Marrone telling us we couldn't
kneel," Thompson wrote. "Thank God we had an owner [Shad Khan] of a minority
who weighed in and got us to kneel together. My job security was on the line
if I supported my people."

RELATED | See more Jacksonville Jaguars coverage

When the Jaguars played the Baltimore Ravens in London in September 2017, at
least 15 players took a knee while owner Shad Khan and the rest of the team,
including coaches and training staff, locked arms during the playing of the
anthem.

It was a show of unity at the time to protest President Donald Trump's
controversial remarks about firing NFL players that kneeled during the
national anthem that began in 2016 by former San Francisco 49ers quarterback
Colin Kaepernick's to call attention to the issues of racial inequality and
police brutality.

Thompson posted on Tuesday that he had a healthy conversation with Marrone
Monday, stating that they spoke of his career's work on equality and his
efforts to make his players feel supported as well as the need to separate his
actions from others in the organization.

''But, we also spoke of a time when the organization had a third party come in
and speak to the team in an attempt to convince us to change our stance,''
Thompson wrote. ''The reality is - the environment that was created in our
facility wasn't safe for everyone to kneel peacefully in protest.

''At least 60% of the team is of minority, including the owner, yet every
player and coach across the league was scared to get 'Kaepernick'd, voices
muffled by fear.

Thompson stated the Jaguars now have the opportunity for a do-over, and he's
hopeful Marrone's activism will lead the change for change this time around.

Thompson took exception to NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell's statement in the
wake of Floyd's death, "NFL family is greatly saddened by the tragic events
across our country and the protesters' reactions to these incidents reflect
the pain, anger, and frustration that so many of us feel."

Several NFL players, including Eric Reed and Kenny Stills, along with
Thompson, criticized Goodell's statement as hypocrisy because of the way the
league handled Kaepernick's kneeling protests.

A free agent, Kaepernick has remained unsigned since his final season with San
Francisco in 2016.

title: Former Jaguars DB Peyton Thompson speaks out about franchise, league regarding social issues
html:
Former Jaguars safety Peyton Thompson spoke out on Twitter that the NFL and all of its organizations continue to release statements of fluff in the aftermath of George Floyd's death.

And Thompson, who played in Jacksonville from 2014-17, stated that former Jaguars top executive Tom Coughlin and Coach Doug Marrone told players they couldn't kneel during the playing of the national anthem in 2017.

"I specifically remember Tom Coughlin and Doug Marrone telling us we couldn't kneel," Thompson wrote. "Thank God we had an owner [Shad Khan] of a minority who weighed in and got us to kneel together. My job security was on the line if I supported my people."

RELATED | See more Jacksonville Jaguars coverage

When the Jaguars played the Baltimore Ravens in London in September 2017, at least 15 players took a knee while owner Shad Khan and the rest of the team, including coaches and training staff, locked arms during the playing of the anthem.

It was a show of unity at the time to protest President Donald Trump's controversial remarks about firing NFL players that kneeled during the national anthem that began in 2016 by former San Francisco 49ers quarterback Colin Kaepernick's to call attention to the issues of racial inequality and police brutality.

Thompson posted on Tuesday that he had a healthy conversation with Marrone Monday, stating that they spoke of his career's work on equality and his efforts to make his players feel supported as well as the need to separate his actions from others in the organization.

''But, we also spoke of a time when the organization had a third party come in and speak to the team in an attempt to convince us to change our stance,'' Thompson wrote. ''The reality is - the environment that was created in our facility wasn't safe for everyone to kneel peacefully in protest.

''At least 60% of the team is of minority, including the owner, yet every player and coach across the league was scared to get 'Kaepernick'd, voices muffled by fear.

Thompson stated the Jaguars now have the opportunity for a do-over, and he's hopeful Marrone's activism will lead the change for change this time around.

Thompson took exception to NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell's statement in the wake of Floyd's death, "NFL family is greatly saddened by the tragic events across our country and the protesters' reactions to these incidents reflect the pain, anger, and frustration that so many of us feel."

Several NFL players, including Eric Reed and Kenny Stills, along with Thompson, criticized Goodell's statement as hypocrisy because of the way the league handled Kaepernick's kneeling protests.

A free agent, Kaepernick has remained unsigned since his final season with San Francisco in 2016.
